summary: Paul Merson reignited his criticism of Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was substituted on for just seven minutes in a 0-0 draw against Burnley. Merson had previously questioned Townsend's place in the England squad, suggesting that if he could make the team, anyone could. Despite this, Townsend scored a crucial equalizer for England in a friendly against Italy, prompting Merson to acknowledge his mistake and express his pleasure at Townsend's success. Townsend responded to Merson's earlier comments on Twitter after his goal, highlighting the irony of Merson's criticism. Although any animosity seemed to have faded, Merson continued to make jabs at Townsend following the match against Burnley.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. If Muto moves to Chelsea this summer, he will be loaned to their Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem for the next season. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013 and recently graduated with an economics degree, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances and earned 11 international caps for Japan. Although he appreciates Chelsea's offer, Muto has not yet decided on the move. The club's interest is reportedly unrelated to their recent £200million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, which will begin in the 2015-16 season.

A large-scale study published in the journal Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, involving over 12,000 two-year-olds, indicated that antibiotic exposure, especially repeated prescriptions, is associated with increased body mass, particularly in boys. The study suggests that antibiotics may disrupt gut bacteria, potentially leading to increased appetite and weight gain. The findings raise concerns about the role of antibiotics in the childhood obesity epidemic, highlighting the need for careful use of these medications. Additionally, previous research links antibiotic use in infants to higher risks of eczema and digestive issues, amid worries about antibiotic over-prescription leading to superbugs.

A Buckingham Palace guard experienced an embarrassing moment when he slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, which was caught on camera by a holidaymaker, occurred as the guard took his position in the sentry box, causing him to lose his footing, knock his bearskin, and drop his rifle. The young guard quickly got back on his feet, visibly embarrassed as he realized many people had witnessed the fall. Tourists often gather to watch this daily event, which features fully operational soldiers, not just ceremonial guards. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E networks are remaking the iconic 1977 miniseries "Roots," which tells the story of Kunta Kinte, an African slave and his descendants. The new version, set to air in 2016, will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, and will be co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, who starred in the original. The remake aims to be "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. The producers hope to reach a new generation of viewers, highlighting the ongoing relevance of Kunta Kinte's story in the context of modern racial issues.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler, who alleges that aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978. On his first day of work, Lawler was allegedly groped and threatened after he entered a bedroom looking for a pen. He left the job the same day and felt haunted by the incident for years. After inquiries into historical child sex abuse cases began, he contacted palace officials, but his complaints were initially ignored. Eventually, his complaint was passed to Scotland Yard, and a retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the video, they share their journey to parenthood, including humorous lyrics about family expectations and their conception timeline. The couple reveals a sonogram at the end of the clip, which was created to inform distant loved ones about the baby. Melissa expressed surprise at the video's popularity, while Jesse noted it has been more fun than they anticipated. The couple is considering making another video after learning the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray color, was featured in key scenes, including those with Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable. The dress was part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who rescued it from being discarded in the 1960s. Other notable auction items included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Gable for $55,000, and a bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year and is notable for Hattie McDaniel's historic Academy Award win.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled over the edge by his parents. The incident occurred on Saturday around 3pm, and the child fell approximately 10 to 12 feet. He was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived and suffered minor bumps and bruises, with a leg injury, but was listed in stable condition at the hospital. Zoo officials confirmed that the cheetahs did not approach the boy during the incident. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the child's mother, and the exhibit was closed following the fall.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been turned to face a house after being non-operational for over two years due to the decommissioning of fixed cameras in the West Midlands. The camera, which previously enforced a 30mph speed limit, was part of a larger shutdown of around 300 outdated devices in March 2013. Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and plans to send an engineer to assess the camera, which may be removed. There are no plans to include this camera in a new pilot program using digital technology. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt expressed his excitement and readiness to run, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle noted the significance of Bolt's participation, anticipating impressive performances. The complete Jamaican team roster will be revealed soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their commitment to Barcelona by attending a Euro League basketball match where Barcelona defeated Real Madrid 85-80. Despite this loss, Real Madrid remains ahead in their Euro League division. Neymar recently led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile and is set to return to La Liga with Barcelona, who are currently four points clear at the top after winning their last El Clasico. The team is aiming for a treble of trophies this season.

Italy is facing an influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 rescued between Friday and Monday, according to the Italian coast guard. There are concerns that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized in the Mediterranean, though the coast guard has not confirmed this incident. The International Organization for Migration reported over 10,000 migrant arrivals in Italy in early 2015, with many coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels, with some captains abandoning their ships.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, although he is unsure of the exact reasons for Sanchez's decision. The Chile forward, who has made a significant impact in English football by scoring 19 goals this season, was pursued by several top clubs after leaving Barcelona. Wenger acknowledged Liverpool's interest in Sanchez, which could have been influenced by their negotiations regarding Luis Suarez. He praised Sanchez's qualities and adaptability, stating he revitalizes the team's dynamics. Additionally, Wenger downplayed rumors about a potential summer transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, expressing admiration for Liverpool's development under Brendan Rodgers despite recent challenges.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The 35-year-old four-time Olympic champion aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, challenging the current record of 52.491km set by Rohan Dennis. Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career, hopes to inspire others to challenge themselves and expects a sell-out crowd for his attempt, with tickets available from April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, described her challenging victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an "eye-opener" for her preparation for the claycourt season. Despite winning the match 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams expressed concern about her readiness for clay, noting that she was playing as if on hard court. The US team ultimately lost 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske suffering a heavy defeat in the doubles match, leading to their relegation to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for improvement, highlighting the potential of having many players in the top 100 to help regain their elite status next year.

River Plate is interested in signing striker Radamel Falcao from Manchester United, where he has struggled on loan, scoring only four Premier League goals. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed a desire for Falcao to return, stating, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao previously played for River Plate for eight years before moving to Porto in 2009 and has recently performed well for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games. He scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate during his time there.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from The X Factor, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop, including a wavy look and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed her excitement about the collaboration, noting her regular use of the product. Mark Hargreaves, her manager, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and the Batiste brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was shot dead by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are in shock over a billboard honoring Torres that was erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. Siler, 26, was fatally shot on March 14 after arming himself during a confrontation with Torres. The billboard, which thanks the community for its support, has been deemed "disrespectful" by Siler's loved ones, with a family friend expressing that it feels like a message of gratitude for Siler's death. The police association stated that the billboard was intended to acknowledge community support and not to offend. Siler was wanted on a felony warrant at the time of the incident, which followed a police chase. The investigation into Siler's shooting is ongoing, while a previous shooting involving Torres was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, with three militants also killed in the fighting. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred in the southeastern town of Negur. Iranian officials have requested Pakistan to apprehend the surviving assailants, as the militants reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian group, has targeted Shiites and has previously claimed attacks on Iranian territory. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and stated that its security agencies are investigating the incident and will apprehend any militants that may have fled into Pakistan.

The passage discusses a recent political exchange in Japan regarding unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs, despite inquiries from former wrestler and lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Nakatani explained that while jets are scrambled to investigate unidentified objects, they typically find birds or other non-extraterrestrial items. Inoki, known for his colorful background in sports and politics, has claimed to have seen a UFO but is uncertain about the existence of aliens. This conversation reflects ongoing discussions among Japanese politicians about potential extraterrestrial threats, dating back to previous inquiries in 2007.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after standing on the rim of a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport, which collapsed beneath him. He was concerned about cleanliness and chose not to sit. After the toilet shattered, he called for help but was too injured to shout. Emergency personnel took him to the hospital, where he received numerous stitches. Initially, he admitted to his friends that he was squatting, but later told police he was sitting to avoid compensation. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl over four years and filming her with a hidden camera in her bathroom. The investigation began when the now 15-year-old girl discovered the camera in March. She reported that Rebbie had been watching her undress and had molested her from ages nine to thirteen. Authorities found 41 videos, including 34 showing victims in the shower, which Rebbie had uploaded to his computer. He admitted to filming multiple victims, specifically targeting the 15-year-old. Rebbie faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy, and is being held on a $500,000 bail, with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series, featured in his book "Daughter and Salary Man," captures unique father-daughter portraits where fathers leap into the air while their daughters smile at the camera. The series aims to showcase the fathers' fun side, contrasting their usual serious demeanor, as they wear sharp suits and the daughters are in casual clothing. The images, set against various Japanese landmarks, have garnered significant online interest for their quirky nature, despite limited information about the project. Some older fathers exhibit pained expressions during their jumps, while others display playful gestures.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the anticipation surrounding the start of the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who is aiming for a return to the England team after being dropped in 2014, is featured in a team photo for Surrey at the KIA Oval. Despite appearing deep in thought, he is in a jovial mood, joking with photographers and teammates. Pietersen's return to Surrey is part of his effort to re-enter the international setup as England prepares for the upcoming summer series.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, has sacked coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a poor performance, including a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazilian international, was initially fired and then reinstated by owner Angelo Massone, but was ultimately dismissed again due to continued poor results. He had been the club's third coach this season, replacing Florin Marin in January. Serbian Vanya Radinovic will take over as the new coach.

Nabil Dirar, a former teammate of Radamel Falcao at Monaco, believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United despite being unhappy in France. Falcao, who struggled after a serious knee injury, has only scored four goals this season, making it unlikely that United will pay £46 million to make his transfer permanent. Dirar suggests that Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League, even though he was not feeling well there.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The suspect, described as very tall and dressed in a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the cash register and approximately $1,500 in cash on Saturday. The incident occurred around 12:30 PM, when the masked man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop in fear. Although no weapons were reported, the robber remains at large, and police encourage anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. The first arrest occurred on March 19, 2023, after she admitted to kissing a 15-year-old pupil and allowing him to touch her breasts. Following this, she was suspended and placed on administrative leave. A second arrest took place on Monday after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was booked into jail and released on a $50,000 bail. The school district stated they took immediate action regarding the situation, ensuring she could not work with students.

A video showing a crocodile swimming in a Puerto Vallarta marina with a dead pet dog in its jaws has garnered over 500,000 views. The incident, witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston on holiday, involved a black dog belonging to a local bike shop owner. Weston described the crocodile holding the dog for hours, while crowds watched in shock. The dog had approached the water's edge out of curiosity. Reactions on social media included horror and disdain for crocodiles, which are common in the area due to urbanization and their proximity to human habitats.

Steve Bruce is determined to keep Hull City in the Premier League despite a recent 2-0 defeat to Southampton, which leaves them just two points above the relegation zone. Initially aiming for 10 wins to ensure survival, Hull has only achieved six so far, and Bruce hopes that eight or nine wins might suffice. The team has six challenging matches ahead, including games against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame and Michael Dawson. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory moved them up to fifth in the league, and manager Ronald Koeman addressed a team discipline issue regarding a penalty incident during the match.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing students at Mitton Manor Primary School to change their SATs exam answers, which invalidated the school's results. Despite the exam session being over, Guffick altered some answers himself and encouraged students to do the same, leading to an investigation by the local education authority. The Department for Education annulled all SATs results for the school following the probe. Guffick admitted to unacceptable professional conduct but claimed he only asked students to make their answers more legible. The panel acknowledged his remorse but deemed his actions deliberate and dishonest, resulting in a prohibition order. He has 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a goalkeeper for Manchester United, has not played much on the pitch but enjoys a happy personal life with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple married in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Lindegaard, who has struggled for playing time at United, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite being linked with a move away from the club, he remains positive, sharing moments with Beqiri on social media. Beqiri, who has a strong Instagram presence, often showcases her modeling work and recently shared her new haircut with her followers.

The auction of 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium at Sotheby's failed to attract any bids, despite an estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid was made by a Sotheby's employee for $260,000. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, were purchased after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson expressed a desire for a new generation to appreciate the iconic signage, which had been displayed since 1976. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding their professional responsibilities after a week of controversy involving Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both players being photographed with shisha pipes. Although Rodgers spoke to them and emphasized the importance of their conduct as elite athletes, he decided not to impose any disciplinary action. With Steven Gerrard returning from suspension, Rodgers is focused on leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management, reflecting on the lessons learned from past near-misses in competitions.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, shared a photo relaxing with his dog after returning to London from international duty, where he helped Germany secure a 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He missed Arsenal's last match against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. Despite rumors of him being seen in a nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger dismissed those claims. Ozil has been performing well since returning from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January, and expressed that he is adjusting well to English football, enjoying the demanding schedule of matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title and has a contract until 2016. Bartomeu emphasized that Enrique is focused on the team's goals and praised his preparation for matches. Barcelona recently won against Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his deal until 2020 and worth approximately £100,000 per week. This agreement follows discussions that began at the start of the season, as Henderson had 14 months left on his previous contract. He is the third key player to secure a contract extension under manager Brendan Rodgers, joining Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, who has shown significant improvement and contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season, is a candidate to succeed Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Meanwhile, talks with Raheem Sterling regarding his contract are on hold until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis wants to remain at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He has struggled to secure the left back position at Chelsea but expresses happiness at the club. Luis emphasizes the importance of focus as Chelsea approaches a challenging Premier League title run-in, with manager Jose Mourinho urging the team to concentrate on winning their remaining nine matches.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out George North during a match on March 27. Initially suspended for being 'reckless,' Hughes's red card was rescinded following an outcry and new evidence presented at the appeal hearing. North, who suffered a concussion and was left unconscious, has been advised to take at least a month off. Many, including Wasps players and former England players, criticized the initial ban as unjust. Hughes is now free to play but is not in the squad for the upcoming match against London Welsh.

A fiery sunset in Washington, caused by wildfires in southeastern Siberia, captivated locals, including Seattle native Tim Durkan, who shared aerial photos. The fires, initially started by farmers, grew uncontrollably due to strong winds, destroying villages. Smoke from the fires was carried across the Pacific, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red sunsets result from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing reds and oranges to dominate. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their vivid hue.

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. Fortunately, the car was recovered after a tip from a man who recognized it. Upon its return, Schoenig found that the car had been altered with red rims and detailing. Instead of being upset, she humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. However, she is now getting the car professionally cleaned due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Additionally, she is creating a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who helped recover her car.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they do not qualify for the Champions League this season. The team, currently in fourth place, faces pressure after a recent loss to Manchester United, with their European hopes uncertain. The top three Premier League teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth must win a qualifying round. The City squad has approximately £12 million at stake for reaching this goal. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team's poor performance, stating they have let their season deteriorate after starting strong. The club is also at risk of losing out on signing top players like Juventus' Paul Pogba, who is also a target for Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane. The match featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were Mancunian. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick, showcasing his skills. Despite a competitive first half, City struggled to equalize, with notable attempts from both sides. The victory leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough in the league, while City has lost both of their playoff matches. The game highlighted the potential of young talents from both teams.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap during a match against England, where Hart also celebrated his 50th cap. Hart expressed admiration for Buffon's career and noted that he continues to learn from him at 37 years old. Hart, who is 10 years younger, expressed pride in reaching his milestone and his desire to continue playing well for both club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery in 67 cities. The restaurant will charge a nine percent service fee, with delivery fees starting at $5. Previously, Chipotle had declined offers from third-party delivery services but has now opted for Postmates, which uses independent contractors for deliveries. The chain has been gaining popularity, with notable customers like presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton spotted at their locations. Other franchises, including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, are urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all charges related to the 2013 attack. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard expressed their family's suffering after losing their son and dealing with their daughter's severe injuries. They advocate for Tsarnaev to serve life in prison without the possibility of parole, arguing that pursuing the death penalty would prolong their pain through years of appeals. The Richards emphasize their desire to move forward and heal, stating they speak only for themselves in this plea.

A custom-built Boeing 747 has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing approximately £400 million over three years. This unique jet, designed for a single owner but capable of accommodating dozens of guests, features multiple lounges, a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, and an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. The interior resembles a high-end hotel, with spaces for relaxation, work, and meetings, including a master bedroom and a conference room. The design prioritizes luxury and comfort, moving away from traditional airplane seating to create a lavish atmosphere.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station from Cape Canaveral, Florida. While the launch was successful, the attempt to land the rocket on a floating barge failed as it tipped over after landing. SpaceX founder Elon Musk emphasized the importance of reusing rockets to significantly reduce space access costs. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the ISS and return with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash. This mission marks SpaceX's sixth trip to the ISS and was the second attempt after a weather-related scrub.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at a new chapel in Las Vegas, launched through a contest with NBC's Today show for an Elvis-themed wedding. The winning couple will marry at the Graceland Wedding Chapel in the Westgate Hotel on April 23, with Priscilla in attendance. They will receive a free reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized the event's seriousness, stating there will be no impersonators involved. The chapel is part of a permanent Graceland exhibit showcasing Elvis's artifacts outside Memphis. Couples must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve to win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite a challenging season. After a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, where both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet made their 47th appearances of the season, Liverpool is four points behind City. Henderson emphasized the importance of the win following disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal, and Joe Allen added a second, marking his first goal at Anfield. Allen acknowledged a potential penalty for Newcastle but focused on the significance of the win for Liverpool's campaign.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, crucial for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves in the second half. This win allowed Roma to move four points ahead of rivals Lazio, while Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches. The match was marked by tight security due to past incidents, but it proceeded without issues. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, but Pjanic's performance was pivotal.

Doncaster Rovers are having a disappointing season in League One, currently stuck in mid-table. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town ended in a goalless draw, which was unexciting for fans. The media team struggled to create match highlights, ultimately producing a brief 27-second video featuring only 14 seconds of actual match action.

The passage describes the unique bond between Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid, showcasing their interactions through touch. Giroux gently massages the fish in its tank, which appears to enjoy the sensation, often returning for more after swimming away. He previously removed two other fish from the tank due to bullying, leading to increased sociability in his pet. Giroux feeds the fish by hand and engages in daily play, noting that the fish becomes frustrated if not interacted with. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid first bred in Taiwan in 1986, is depicted as a responsive and affectionate pet.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team and the need for careful management of his fiery character. Stokes, known for his aggressive play, faced challenges in the past, including an incident where he broke his wrist after hitting a locker. Despite a slight back issue, he is expected to play in Barbados. England coach Peter Moores has advised Stokes on how to channel his aggression positively, especially after a clash with Marlon Samuels. The team values Stokes' natural exuberance and potential to contribute runs and wickets, but they also recognize the importance of controlling his aggression. The passage highlights the team's desire to develop both Stokes and Chris Jordan, suggesting that they will benefit from playing together as they grow into the international game.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams have 11 points in Group B, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. Wales recently achieved a 3-0 victory over Israel, boosting hopes for automatic qualification for the tournament. The Football Association of Wales reported high ticket demand, leading to a sell-out. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevented this, and the Wales squad prefers the Cardiff City Stadium, where they last played in 2011.

England coach John Peacock has announced the squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the Young Lions will defend their title after winning last year. They qualified with a perfect record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, starting their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad features players from various Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock, who is making his debut in the squad. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the previous qualifiers. England's other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from the club's youth system. He has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, having previously declined a move to Barcelona's academy to focus on his studies. City has engaged in talks with Anderlecht's chairman to negotiate a compensation package, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure promising players for the future.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort found strangled and beaten in a Fulham flat at the end of March. Her body showed injuries to the head and neck, and she was pronounced dead at the scene. The man has been bailed and is expected to return for further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. She had recently moved to London from Mexico and worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and seeks information about her last days.

Dawn, a woman who has experienced seven miscarriages, expressed her distress on The Jeremy Kyle Show after discovering that her family friend, Jamie, had stolen £207 intended for a gravestone for her deceased child, Daniel James. During the show, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, leading to an emotional confrontation where Dawn felt betrayed. She had been saving for a £500 gravestone and was devastated by the theft, which she believed undermined her efforts to honor her child's memory. After the revelation, she left the stage in tears, supported by her partner.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women and children, who had been captured during the group's takeover of northern Iraq last summer. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders, although the exact motivation remains unclear. The Yazidis, a minority group with a long history of persecution, faced severe violence from ISIS, including killings, rapes, and enslavement. The U.S. and an international coalition responded with humanitarian aid and airstrikes against ISIS. The Yazidi population in northern Iraq is estimated at 500,000, making up less than 1% of the country's total population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, has had an impressive season, breaking into the first team and the England squad. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation showcasing his best goals and celebrations has been released by Copa90, highlighting key moments such as his 20th Premier League goal and his England debut. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', comes ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool despite the team's lack of trophies and likely failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher believes that a single game should not determine a manager's future and emphasizes the need for effective signings to improve the squad. He acknowledges the challenges faced this season but expresses hope for next season's success. Additionally, Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, highlighting his commitment to helping underprivileged areas.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security deemed it a security risk. His father, Phil, criticized the security staff's actions as "over-zealous" and "ludicrous," especially given the thorough pat-down James received. The family was in a hurry to catch their flight to Lanzarote and could not contest the confiscation. Upon returning from their holiday, they purchased a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions, stating that regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items, which includes replica or model guns.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He outlines specific requirements for his ideal partner, including a love for pets, being a non-drinker and non-smoker, and being fit and attractive. Rich describes himself as athletic, tattooed, and successful, offering benefits like a company car, phone, and gym membership to the successful candidate. He emphasizes the need for reliability, honesty, and cooking skills, while also stating that he is generous with spending on his partner. Rich's ad specifies that former partners need not apply, and he encourages interested women to make offers.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is advocating for significant changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12, facing opposition from the Premier League. He proposes that 'home-grown' players should be those trained in England for three years before age 18. Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—support Dyke's initiatives, warning that failure to implement these changes could hinder England's competitiveness in football. Currently, only 36.8% of Premier League starters are eligible for England selection. The former managers acknowledge the decline in English talent at the top level and emphasize the need for more opportunities for young players, despite recent successes in Euro 2016 qualifying.

Demelza Poldark has recently given birth to a baby daughter, which will be showcased in the upcoming episode of the show. Aidan Turner's character, Ross Poldark, expresses his affection for Demelza, despite their marriage being initially based on duty. However, the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy appears unrealistic, as she goes from announcing her pregnancy to being eight months along and then giving birth in a very short span of time. This rapid progression has drawn attention from fans, who have humorously noted the show's tendency to accelerate pregnancy timelines, comparing it to a previous character's experience.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused on their own performance and not to worry about relegation rivals as they approach a crucial match against Swansea. The Foxes are currently bottom of the Premier League but have gained momentum with back-to-back wins, including a vital 3-2 victory over West Brom, thanks to an injury-time goal from Jamie Vardy. Pearson emphasizes that their future is in their own hands and stresses the importance of concentrating on their own games to improve their chances of survival, while acknowledging the potential for over-optimism among players.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest migration of any mammal, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may belong to this population rather than the endangered western gray whales, of which only about 150 are believed to exist. This finding prompts a reevaluation of the genetic distinctions between the two species.

Residents on Hokkaido Island, Japan, experienced an unexpected change when 1,000ft of seabed emerged overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu. The land rose up to 50ft above sea level, likely due to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow. Local residents reported no sounds or tremors during the event. The new land measures approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Authorities do not expect further expansion and have clarified that this event is not related to a recent earthquake in Kathmandu. Marine life, including seaweed and sea urchins, remains attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain and expressed his love for the club, stating he is happy and wants to sign a new contract. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match, Van der Wiel remains committed to PSG. However, with the club linked to Dani Alves, his future at the club may be uncertain.

Carlos Tevez has been advised to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to Boca Juniors, his former club in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus runs until the end of next season, Tevez has expressed a desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors is close to finalizing a deal, but their president, Daniel Angelici, emphasized that Tevez must first end his contract with Juventus. Tevez, currently the top scorer in Serie A with 17 goals, has always intended to finish his career at Boca Juniors. His international manager, Tata Martino, stated that Tevez's club situation will not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola tore the left trouser leg of his grey trousers while celebrating his team's impressive 6-1 victory over Porto. The win secured Bayern's place in the semi-finals, overcoming a two-goal deficit from the first leg. Guardiola humorously noted he would need to buy new trousers for the next match. The match featured goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski, showcasing Bayern's dominance over a stunned Porto side.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. The incident involved three vehicles and resulted in several injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were the first to be airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. The highway has been closed with diversions in place, and emergency crews had to free one person trapped in a vehicle.

This weekend, Arsenal will face Chelsea in a crucial Premier League match, with Arsenal's Mesut Ozil excitedly showcasing his new Apple Watch ahead of the game. Ozil, who has scored four goals this season, shared his enthusiasm on Instagram, comparing the watch to the one used by Michael Knight from Knight Rider. Arsenal, currently 10 points behind Chelsea, has welcomed back Jack Wilshere, who recently returned from a five-month injury layoff. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be a key player for Arsenal, but his fitness remains a concern, drawing parallels to the injury struggles of Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby on Sunday, despite having sent off three players from Manchester United and Manchester City this season. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for an upcoming match after receiving a red card during an international game. Clattenburg has faced accusations of bias towards United but has only issued two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players. The derby is significant as Manchester United has recently gained momentum with five consecutive league wins, while Manchester City has struggled. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has stirred controversy by accusing the Queensland Government of viewing embattled MP Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string" following allegations of domestic violence against Gordon. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, expressed sympathy for Gordon, who recently left the Queensland Labor Party but plans to remain in parliament as an independent. Katter questioned why it was assumed Gordon would resign, contrasting it with past cases in federal parliament. His statement has faced backlash on social media for its terminology, but Katter defended his choice of words, citing his own experiences with racism and asserting that he aimed to highlight racial overtones in the situation. He emphasized that Gordon would not compromise his independence like other independents have in the past.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, is using her passion for dance to challenge stereotypes associated with her cerebral palsy and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and societal judgment, she aims to change perceptions of disabilities through her enthusiastic videos. Dayna emphasizes that she is similar to her peers, even if she does things differently, and hopes to encourage people to look beyond her disability. She has also started motivational speaking at local schools to further spread her message of positivity and resilience.

Orlando City has shown interest in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez would attract a significant Latin-American fanbase in Orlando, where Kaka is the captain. However, he is also being pursued by eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, with United willing to sell for around £8 million. Additionally, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from several European clubs after rejecting United's initial offer.

A gang of at least three individuals set a car on fire at a gas station in South Los Angeles early Saturday morning after attempting to carjack the driver. The incident occurred around 12:15am when the driver, who has not been identified, got into an argument with the suspects while pumping gas. They poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and ignited it, with two passengers inside. Fortunately, no one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large, with surveillance video being utilized in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can practice again. Despite these allegations, he received high patient satisfaction ratings, with a perfect score on HealthGrades.com. His practice was located on a residential street in Lamoni, and he has not worked at his former practice for some time.

The United States is lodging a complaint with Russia after a Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea. The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew reporting aggressive maneuvers by the Russian pilot. Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off, which U.S. officials denied. This incident follows a previous complaint from the U.S. regarding a close encounter between a Russian jet and a RC-135U last year. The Pentagon plans to address the matter through diplomatic channels.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case and locked to the vehicle, but the thief broke the rear window, used a rope to pull the case out, and left behind evidence including skid marks and a broken case handle. Other items, including the agent's gear bag and clothing, were also stolen, with some found at a nearby Residence Inn. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was informed of the theft prior to the presidential visit. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and police are unsure if the agent's car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra. A jury heard that Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the crime. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa's mental state had declined leading up to and during the incident, evidenced by fluctuating moods and a trail of feces from the crime scene. Mullen stated that Costa likely did not understand his actions due to his compromised mental state. The prosecution suggested Costa was feigning memory loss, but Mullen disagreed, emphasizing the likelihood of Costa's dementia. Costa's mental state is crucial for the jury's decision, as it could lead to a not guilty verdict if proven unstable at the time of the attack.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after he missed a penalty in a 1-0 victory against Burnley. Barkley took the penalty in the 10th minute instead of Leighton Baines, who has a strong penalty record. Although there was no conflict this time, it recalled a previous incident where Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and missed. Martinez stated that Barkley was justified in taking the penalty and praised his willingness to take responsibility. Despite the miss, it did not affect the outcome as Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal of the match later on.

Two passengers were found dead in a stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, and it appears to be a murder-suicide, according to Holland America Line. The incident was reported at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday, and the cabin was secured while authorities, including the FBI, were notified and began their investigation. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time. The deceased were discovered by cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced after a 2-2 draw against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in Willemstad. The decisive goal in the second leg was scored by Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert has a personal connection to Curacao and has experience as a World Cup player and assistant coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, a seasoned player with a successful career in major European competitions, believes that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy. Currently, Leicester is seven points from safety with only eight games left. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester after a decade at Inter Milan, remains optimistic about their chances despite not winning since January. He views the challenge of keeping Leicester in the Premier League as a key objective and expresses satisfaction with his time at the club, indicating a possibility of extending his stay beyond his one-year contract.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma is at risk of being banned from seeing her two children, both under five, due to her refusal to stop drinking and partying. Her mother, Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old, is threatening to prevent Gemma from seeing them after discovering her substance abuse and suspected theft. Debbie claims Gemma is unfit to be a mother, citing her history of irresponsible behavior and past thefts. Despite Gemma's claims of not stealing, she has admitted to taking money and items from her mother. Debbie, feeling overwhelmed, is considering a complete ban on Gemma's access to the children, expressing concern for their well-being and her daughter's lack of responsibility.

After Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead against Manchester United, Sky Sports pundits expressed their belief that a foul occurred in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United's Radamel Falcao, which led to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas played to Hazard for the goal. Pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that Terry's tackle should have been penalized, with Souness describing it as a "decent forearm smash" and Henry expressing sympathy for Falcao. Redknapp acknowledged that while Falcao could have stayed on his feet, Terry's challenge was still a foul.

Hillary Scott's tour bus for Lady Antebellum caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, and dramatic footage of the incident was captured by Michael Barnett. Scott shared a photo of the damaged bus on Instagram, expressing gratitude for their safety and noting that the fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The band's other members were not on the bus, and they are scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a scientist from Dundee University, is exploring the use of space lasers to provide energy for homes by converting sunlight into laser light via satellites equipped with mirrors. This technology could enhance solar power viability in Scotland and aid in disaster recovery. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further testing is planned in Portugal. Unlike fictional portrayals, these lasers will not be powerful enough to cause destruction or be used as weapons. Additionally, researchers in Tokyo are developing a separate laser system for the International Space Station to target and eliminate space debris, which also cannot be weaponized. Quarterman has expressed concerns about the control of his satellite technology.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of targeting young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire. He was last seen leaving a hospital on Tuesday evening. Munden, who has a "fanatical obsession" with small girls, was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl. He has a heavy build, is about 5ft 8ins tall, and may have shaved his beard before disappearing. Munden was previously convicted of multiple sexual offences, including possessing indecent images of children. Authorities have launched a manhunt for him and are urging anyone with information on his whereabouts to come forward.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts received from Donald Sterling, following a lawsuit by his wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly accused Stiviano of exploiting wealthy older men, claiming that Donald used their money to buy her luxury items, including cars and a duplex. Stiviano defended herself, stating there was nothing wrong with the gifts. The court's decision is seen as a victory for the Sterling family, establishing that an injured spouse can recover damages from the recipient of such gifts. Donald Sterling's downfall was triggered by racist remarks captured in an audio recording, leading to his ban from the NBA and a $2.5 million fine.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer activities and urged the club to acquire four key players: a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top striker, to enhance their chances of winning the Premier League. Following a goalless draw with Chelsea, he expressed doubts about Olivier Giroud's ability to lead the team to the title, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. Henry emphasized the need for Arsenal to strengthen their squad with players of high quality, similar to those acquired by Chelsea, to foster competitiveness and improve their title prospects.

A young woman testified in court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. She revealed her fears for future relationships and the lasting effects of the abuse, stating she didn't understand it was wrong at the time. After learning of Van Ryn's arrest, she felt compelled to speak out but has since struggled with depression, self-harm, and suicidal thoughts. She expressed concern about Van Ryn's potential release and its impact on her life. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, is recovering from a serious knee injury that has kept him out of action since March 2014. He has recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s and feels he is improving, stating, "I am feeling good, I'm feeling better and better." Gnabry is optimistic about his return to the first team after a year-long absence.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling 70 feet from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while trying to evade a taxi fare following a night out with friends. After catching a cab home, Phillips and his friends attempted to use an ATM but ran away when they realized they didn't have enough money. In the dark, Phillips leapt over a fence and fell down the cliff, becoming disoriented. His body was discovered the next day by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Phillips likely did not understand the danger he was in at the time. He had been visiting his mother for Christmas and worked for the clothing label Pretty Green.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delays have not received compensation, despite the HM Passport Office making a £42 million profit during the crisis. While managers received bonuses up to £3,500, ministers denied blanket refunds to families who incurred extra costs or missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved from April to January, totaling £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, criticized the lack of compensation and noted that many claims were rejected. The Passport Office struggled with a backlog of 3.6 million applications, leaving many travelers without timely passports.

A 1930s home in Horfield, Bristol, is for sale, retaining original features such as stained-glass windows, an untouched bathroom and kitchen, and vintage food jars. The semi-detached property, priced between £200,000 and £250,000, showcases a wood-panelled hallway, original 1930s cupboards, and a dated mint green and black bathroom. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, potential renovation costs may deter developers. The house will be auctioned on April 30 and is seen as a collector's paradise or a perfect family home for antique enthusiasts.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers but became the starter in the 2012 season after Alex Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage discusses two main subjects: Anne Rice, who was born in New Orleans and later lived in Texas and San Francisco, and Route 495, a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 via the Lincoln Tunnel, facilitating access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, attended Stanway School where he formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon. Blur's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991 but received mixed reviews. The band later achieved worldwide success with their self-titled album in 2001, drawing from various musical influences. Albarn's debut solo album, Everyday Robots, was released on 28 April 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, along with samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia, housing many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP) titled Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes the film "Shooter" (2007), which features Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran played by Mark Wahlberg, who is framed for murder by a rogue private military unit. It also mentions the TV series "Shooter," starring Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile who is drawn back into action upon discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House (also known as House, M.D.) is an American medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his followers. He also received convictions for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, recordings of his songs were commercially released.

Sean Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television and made his film debut in Taps (1981). Throughout the 1980s, he gained critical acclaim for roles in crime dramas such as At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. Penn became a leading actor with his performance in Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination. He received additional nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), before winning two Academy Awards for Best Actor for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001) was an Australian cricketer, regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket as an administrator, selector, and writer for thirty years.

L.A. Reid has held prominent positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group, all under Sony Music Entertainment.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work with the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007). He began his career in 1990 with the band Greta and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he is a member of the band Prophets of Rage, which includes Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Additionally, Rage is mentioned as a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, totaling 34 episodes over two seasons. It was canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, after four episodes of its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention as Texas state treasurer and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards (1935-1982) was a jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an independent EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written and directed by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, was born on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She authored four books from 1984 to 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on July 24, 1783, and died on December 17, 1830. He was instrumental in the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is an ill-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean known for the mysterious disappearances of various aircraft and ships.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers but became the starter in the 2012 season after Alex Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In the 2013 season, Kaepernick, in his first full season as a starter, guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, but they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, advertising is not directed at specific individuals and is conveyed through various mass media, including traditional outlets like newspapers and television, as well as new media such as websites and text messages.
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, and it was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957, to October 19, 1963. He was born on February 10, 1894, and passed away on December 29, 1986.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, around 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at about seventeen or eighteen and stayed until he was thirty-seven. After Plato's death, he left Athens and began tutoring Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is currently the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie year after being selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft. He won four additional championships in the 1980s. After a four-year retirement, he returned to play 32 games in 1996 before retiring for the final time. In 2009, he was recognized by Ebony magazine as one of America's most influential black businessmen and has had various business interests, including being a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The duo gained popularity in 1997 with their television series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (1566-1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603. He ruled both kingdoms in personal union, advocating for a single parliament for England and Scotland. While he achieved many goals in Scotland, he encountered significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British actor and voice-over artist known for narrating the UK's version of Big Brother since 2000 and for his work with Channel 4 until 2011. His distinctive voice and Geordie accent have made him a well-recognized figure in Britain.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, and Bavaria, as well as Poland and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany, covering 18,413 km², and the sixth most populous, with 4 million residents. Saxony has a rich history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine production, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe, alongside the Saale-Unstrut region. Both are located in the former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, and "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" in collaboration with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death. The film is also notable for its popular songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure and is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born on December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, recognized for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and making his directorial debut with Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official responsible for serving as the spokesperson for the U.S. executive branch, particularly regarding the President and policies. Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" due to its fertile soil, features the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, home to major cities Louisville and Lexington. Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and later on pay-per-view. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual pay-per-view event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer, as well as a film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for its service and is the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

The passage discusses three distinct subjects: "Excuse My French," which is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana; a 2014 Egyptian comedy film of the same name directed by Amr Salama, based on his experiences in a public middle school in Egypt; and Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, a British hip hop artist, actor, film director, and producer born on October 22, 1983.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or just disk, is a type of disk storage made of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium, which is sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala faced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. From 1960 to 1996, the country experienced a violent civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, which included genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. In non-medical contexts, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the main character in the ABC television series Lost, which aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes. The first season attracted an average of 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey, born on November 4, 1969, is an American actor known for his preference for dramatic roles since 2011. Notable films he has appeared in include The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. Robert Palmer is a writer known for his books, particularly "Deep Blues," as well as his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone. He produced blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film "Deep Blues," and he played clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941. Gutzon Borglum designed the sculpture and led the project from 1927 until his death, with Lincoln assisting him. After Gutzon's passing, Lincoln took over leadership of the construction project.

The film "Underdog," directed by Frederik Du Chau, features a screenplay by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, and Octavia Blake, who are among the first to return to Earth from a space habitat called "The Ark" after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also features Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke's mother, Marcus Kane, a council member, and Thelonious Jaha, the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that, despite facing financial issues, is recognized for its success in raising awareness and funds. It also provided valuable lessons and inspiration for future projects, particularly Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized as a significant filmmaker in India, known for transforming the Tamil film industry and changing the landscape of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine, articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Douglas, who were candidates for the U.S. Senate from Illinois. These debates, known as The Great Debates of 1858, attracted large audiences from neighboring states due to the significant national issue of slavery.
