The research, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, debunked the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women avoid asking for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or adhering to stereotypes. The study also indicated that younger workers under 40, regardless of gender, are asking for and receiving pay rises at similar rates, suggesting a shift in negotiating behavior. Professor Andrew Oswald noted the findings point to potential discrimination against women, while Dr. Amanda Goodall highlighted that younger women are negotiating more successfully than older generations.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location despite conducting ground investigations. The two existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council has ruled out all identified council-owned sites due to various issues such as size, ground conditions, and legal restrictions. After the cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature an app that allows visitors to access online information from signs and posters at the event. This includes videos and band interviews. Notable acts this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Skerryvore. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that the augmented reality experience enhances enjoyment and enables global interaction with the festival, providing updates, ticket purchasing, and a taste of the festival atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority reported that he suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of overheating and post-race ataxia, he had no significant underlying health issues at the time of his death. Trainer Oliver Sherwood praised him as the "horse of a lifetime." The BHA emphasized the rarity of such incidents and expressed a commitment to understanding their causes and prevention.

A 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004. Ayrton, now 34 and identifying as Davina, has been charged with raping the teenager while two others were asleep. The victim reported the incident after drinking a small amount of alcohol and clearly remembered the events. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester, citing concerns for her safety and the risk of failing to attend court. Ayrton changed her name in 2012 and disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014. The case has been described as unusual and challenging.

The Serbian tennis team lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilian players Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This defeat followed Novak Djokovic's unexpected exit from the singles competition, where he was defeated by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world number one, had previously suffered a surprising third-round loss at Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey but later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, featuring over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants are restricted to using only chainsaws to create carvings of animals and people. Last year's champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, has been recovering from a serious foot injury sustained during a World Cup warm-up match in September. He reports being close to returning to play, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations starting in February. Webb is currently in a pre-season training phase and is optimistic about his recovery timeline. He has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region despite other offers. Webb expressed his commitment to playing for Wales and his enjoyment of being with the Ospreys.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents intercepted two men near Sumas, Washington, who were attempting to smuggle 58 pounds of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man fired at the agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. Canadian police later apprehended Nathan Hall, the fugitive. A California driver's license with Hall's photo was found in one of the backpacks. Authorities also arrested Kali Henifin and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who were allegedly involved in the transportation plan. The suspects face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported counseling over 4,500 children in the past year, a significant increase from about 2,400 in 2011-12, highlighting a growing issue of online abuse. Many children, some as young as seven, have experienced torment and fear related to cyber-bullying, which can follow them home and severely impact their lives. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized the need for adults to intervene, as bullying tends to worsen if left unaddressed. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, where the Anti Bullying Alliance collaborates with various stakeholders to tackle the issue. One young caller shared their distress over online bullying, illustrating the emotional toll it takes and the lack of understanding from parents.

The passage discusses a recent UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, which the US chose not to veto, angering Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He accused the White House of helping draft the resolution, a claim the US State Department denied. The resolution states that settlements are illegal under international law and hinder peace efforts. In response, Netanyahu summoned ambassadors of countries that supported the resolution and postponed a vote on new housing in Jerusalem to avoid further tensions with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to present his vision for peace, while Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas views the resolution as a step towards a peace conference in France.

The passage discusses events surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, highlighting tributes from Prince William and political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron. A series of celebrations are planned, including the release of commemorative stamps featuring the Queen and her family, and a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office. The Queen will unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway and light a beacon to celebrate her milestone. Prince William reflects on his royal duties amidst criticism, emphasizing the importance of finding his own way in royal responsibilities. The passage also notes criticism from the republican group Republic regarding the media coverage of the Queen's birthday.

In a match between Cheltenham Town and West Ham United, the Premier League side secured a 2-0 victory with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew before half-time. Cheltenham, unchanged from their recent league defeat, had a few close attempts but failed to significantly challenge West Ham's goalkeeper. The match marked the end of League Two's representation in the EFL Cup. West Ham made several changes to their lineup after recent losses, while Cheltenham struggled to capitalize on their opportunities. The previous encounter between the two teams at this stage of the competition four years ago also ended in a win for West Ham.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, turned his VW Transporter without seeing the motorcyclist. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not seek jail time for Werner, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse. Werner expressed remorse but could not explain the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, London, is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists returning from Syria. He left the UK in January 2022, adopting the name Abu Daigham al-Britani, and became known for his online presence while fighting with the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. Khawaja posted videos and images of his experiences, including gruesome content. After a year, he attempted to return to the UK, faking his death and seeking help from his cousin, who was later charged with assisting an offender. Upon arrival in Dover, police arrested him, and he now faces potential life imprisonment for his actions, having admitted to four offences. Khawaja was held in a high-security unit due to the threat he poses, while a more serious charge of soliciting to murder remains on file.

Jackson, a 22-year-old player, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping the team finish eighth. He is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, as they prepare for the League One play-off final. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and ability to challenge defenders. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season.

National Trust volunteers are clearing bottles that have washed up at Poldhu Cove, believed to have come from a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean during a storm near Land's End in May. While the bottles are sealed, some have leaked, raising concerns about their impact on wildlife and marine life. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated there is no conclusive evidence linking the washed-up bottles to the lost container. Other nearby coves have also been affected, and Cornwall Council, along with various partners, is monitoring the situation. The public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

The incident took place on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in several minor injuries. The road was closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is conducting ongoing inquiries into the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, contributing to Wanderers' second-place finish in League One and their promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has played 83 matches in total. Manager Phil Parkinson noted Dervite's significant contribution towards the end of the last campaign. He is among several players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, who have signed new contracts with Bolton following their promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates criticized Labour for conceding too much, while Labour's Baroness Smith accused the Lib Dems of creating false hope. The two parties had previously collaborated to challenge the government on EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approvals, but their cooperation faltered when MPs rejected amendments. A Labour source described the Lib Dems' actions as grandstanding, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite their history of alliances on various issues, tensions remain, with Labour predicting limited collaboration moving forward.

In the current election, defence is a low priority for most political parties, with public concern focused more on the economy, NHS, and immigration. Despite the increasing global threats, the UK is reducing its military capabilities, with significant cuts to the Army, Navy, and Air Force. The UK has fallen to sixth in global defence spending and may not meet the NATO target of 2% of GDP, with projections suggesting a drop to 1.7% or lower. Political parties are hesitant to commit to protecting defence budgets amid broader spending cuts. The renewal of the UK's nuclear deterrent, Trident, is contentious, with varying party positions on its future. The Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers may face operational challenges due to insufficient crew and equipment. Overall, there is a growing concern about the UK's military readiness and capability amidst budget constraints and political indecision.

Barcelona maintains that they have not committed any offense regarding the signing of Neymar, for which they paid £48.6m, with his parents receiving £34m. The total cost to the club, including various fees, amounts to £106.8m. Following accusations of financial misconduct, former president Sandro Rosell resigned and is under investigation, which he denies. A Spanish judge has allowed investigations into the transfer to continue, as there are claims that the actual cost of Neymar was higher than reported. Barcelona has made an additional tax payment of approximately 13.55 million euros to clarify their fiscal obligations, while asserting that they believe their original tax payment was correct. Neymar has performed well, scoring seven goals in 18 league matches this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, died in a crash involving a Mazda driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for older drivers, emphasizing the need for safety measures to prevent such accidents. Luciw, a father, was described as generous and kind-hearted, and his family expressed their grief over his untimely death. The driver of the van, Andy Harrington, who sustained serious injuries, also called for medical examinations for retired drivers. Currently, UK drivers over 70 only complete a self-assessment every three years to renew their licenses, with no mandatory medical or driving tests. The DVLA stated that there are no plans to restrict licenses based on age, citing a lack of evidence that older drivers are more prone to serious accidents. Age UK highlighted the importance of supporting older individuals in driving safely to maintain their independence.

The passage discusses concerns raised by women regarding the safety of implants used for treating incontinence, particularly after experiencing severe side effects. Two members of the original review group resigned in protest over a perceived diluted report. Independent expert Alison Britton will assess the review process, aiming to identify lessons for the future. The report recommends that procedures for pelvic organ prolapse should not be routinely offered, suggests a range of treatment options for patients, and mandates the reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a complete ban on the procedures, the health secretary stated that the power to ban lies with the UK regulatory body. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, acknowledged difficulties in achieving consensus among panel members and faced criticism from the public gallery. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh implants, with more than 400 currently pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12 at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan expressed excitement about the record being broken but raised concerns about whether Muir's race met UK Athletics' criteria for record-breaking, noting that Muir was the only competitor in a mixed 3K and 5K race. British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be ratified, as there is no requirement for drug testing if doping control is absent. McColgan praised Muir's potential, suggesting she could run even faster, and noted similarities between Muir's race and her own record-breaking experience. Muir previously set a British 1500m record and competed in the Olympic final in 2016.

Jung won gold on Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou, who had an infection. Astier Nicolas from France took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze, while GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, competing 10 months after being in an induced coma from a fall, had a strong show-jumping performance but fell to 21st after a poor cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth. The passage also invites readers to engage with equestrian activities at Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics.

Briton Andy Murray, 30, won his match against 29th seed Fabio Fognini with a score of 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, securing his place in the last 16 for the 11th time after two hours and 39 minutes. Despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set, Murray rallied to win five consecutive games. He will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced, winning 6-4, 6-1 against Maria Sakkari. Murray described the match as tense and acknowledged that he didn't play his best tennis at times, but was relieved to finish in four sets before potential changes in conditions due to fading light. The match featured dramatic moments, including Fognini's ankle injury and a point penalty for obscenity. Murray expressed satisfaction with his progress and plans to improve his rhythm before the next match.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven for a sudden death. Police found patrons still at the bar, with alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered a three-month closure of the bar. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, while James Thomas faced one count. The court noted that licensing laws were not strictly followed, and O'Neill had a poor record. She was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, during the launch of the Ulster Unionist party's manifesto, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination and framed the upcoming election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive issue. His comments drew attention, particularly after senior party member Danny Kennedy distanced himself from them. Nesbitt expressed confidence in his position, stating he had no regrets and would not retract his words. He indicated a preference for partnering with the SDLP over Sinn Féin if they entered Stormont. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', outlines priorities such as addressing waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and supporting the LGBT community, while also criticizing the past decade of governance by the DUP and Sinn Féin for incompetence and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will be presented to the assembly to align Northern Ireland with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This initiative, known as 'Turing's Law', will allow for posthumous pardons and enable living men to apply for pardons. The motion aims to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland and has received executive agreement. Sugden emphasized the importance of addressing past injustices and indicated that the motion will be considered by the assembly soon.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a race behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12, setting a new Scottish record and moving to second on the British all-time list. Muir expressed her pleasure at breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 record and currently holds the Scottish records for both 1500m and mile. She aims to secure an Olympic spot for Great Britain at the upcoming trials in Birmingham. Muir recently won an 800m race in France and is balancing her training with her veterinary studies, having completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage mentions that there are pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as the "most excellent" for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi likely acted on behalf of the Russian state in the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006, although they deny wrongdoing. Litvinenko, who had defected to the UK and accused the FSB of corruption and murder, died after ingesting polonium-210 in tea during a meeting with the suspects. Horwell emphasized that while the evidence suggests state involvement, it does not implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin directly. He noted that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death and expressed concerns about the potential public health risks from polonium exposure. The suspects have not been extradited from Russia, and attempts to bring them to trial for murder are unlikely. The inquiry into the case has been adjourned.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the captain of Australia's Twenty20 team, in addition to already leading the one-day side, following Aaron Finch's injury. David Warner, 28, will serve as Smith's vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and suitability for the role, especially after Michael Clarke's retirement post-Ashes defeat. Smith has previously captained the team during Clarke's recovery and has a strong Test record. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, has matured and is seen as a key senior figure. Together, they will lead Australia in upcoming limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Mr. Farron, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, expressed strong support for LGBT-plus rights and prioritizes defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender individuals. He avoided directly answering whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating that "we are all sinners." When questioned about his past vote against the Equality Bill in 2007, he clarified his commitment to equality and explained that his concerns were related to individual liberties, although he did not specify those concerns. He emphasized his dedication to ensuring equal access under the law for all, regardless of sexuality.

Accord Healthcare will utilize the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. The company aims to fill many positions with ex-Sanofi employees and believes this investment will positively impact the area. Newcastle City Council leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, praised the announcement as beneficial for Newcastle and the North East, enhancing their reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that produces over 130 products for around 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving his position as the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are also departing through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Opposition leader Stephen Flynn noted that these departures reflect the council's struggle to retain senior staff and anticipates more exits in the future. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for the trio's dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, after experiencing a crash at this year's TT and facing mechanical issues with the Fireblade bike, announced he is stepping back from road racing on Hondas for the year. He clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing entirely. He did not participate in the North West 200 following a teammate's crash and will also miss the Ulster Grand Prix. He expressed dissatisfaction with the TT experience, feeling more like a test rider than a competitor. Following recent testing, he informed his team that the bike wouldn't be competitive for the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. He expressed interest in racing classic and unconventional bikes instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorships in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost its first presidential poll last month. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's losses included key northern states and Adamawa, though it retained control in Rivers State. The party's support was mainly in the south-east, while the APC dominated most northern states and Lagos. The elections experienced some violence but were generally more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP, having been in power for 16 years, faces a period of introspection and rebuilding due to allegations of corruption and failure to address insurgency issues.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore's Temasek, of ignoring unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to haze in Singapore and Malaysia, caused by slash-and-burn methods in Indonesia. Olam, which sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, denies these allegations and claims to have a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. The report suggests that Olam's practices may inadvertently support rogue palm oil companies. Temasek, while a majority stakeholder in Olam, asserts it does not direct Olam's operations and supports no-burn policies. The palm oil industry faces criticism for environmental damage and labor issues, with calls for stricter government enforcement of sustainable practices. Additionally, concerns have been raised about Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations, which Olam defends as responsible and transparent.
A restaurant started offering puppy platters after a new law permitted dogs to dine at outdoor restaurants.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is uncertain to play due to a knee issue, having only been a substitute in the last two matches. Derby County's David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing a recent game. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is seeking a starting position after scoring as a substitute in the last match.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted the YouTube ban, citing the launch of a Pakistan-specific version by Google. While many young Pakistanis welcomed this change, some activists are calling for transparency regarding the agreement between Google and the government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed that internet service providers must allow access to YouTube. Google stated that it has a process for the Pakistan government to request content removal, but emphasized that not all requests would be granted. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," which led to protests and fatalities in Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing pressure to withdraw from overseeing the upcoming presidential election due to his shared Swiss nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino. LFA boss Musa Bility has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday. Bility argues that Scala's position violates Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations regarding conflicts of interest. Scala previously withdrew from the 2015 elections to avoid any appearance of conflict, but his spokesman claims there is no conflict this time as there is no incumbent president. The election to replace Sepp Blatter is set for February 26, with five candidates, including Infantino and Prince Ali. Bility, who was denied eligibility to run, has pledged his support to Prince Ali.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning. Their bodies were removed the following afternoon. A forensic investigation is underway, with Det Ch Insp Paul Durham indicating that evidence suggests a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition caused a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is also involved in gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf but resolved the issue after an apology. Morocco's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was secured after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban related to their refusal to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns. Morocco's fine was significantly reduced from $1 million to $50,000. Tunisia's conflict with Caf stemmed from a controversial penalty awarded in a 2015 match against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a demand for an apology to avoid disqualification. After discussions with Caf president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia's issues were resolved, allowing them to participate in the 2017 tournament, where they will compete in Group A against Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, aiming for their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

The passage discusses a mass altercation during a football match at Etihad Stadium, where Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1. City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for violent conduct and Fernandinho a three-match ban for his involvement in the incident. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for the team's actions, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Mae Cymru a rhannau eraill o'r DU yn wynebu rhai o'r cyfraddau goresgyn canser gwaethaf yn y byd datblygedig. Mae cynllun peilot yn Cwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd yn canolbwyntio ar gleifion heb arwyddion clir o ganser, gan ganiatáu i feddygon teulu gyfeirio cleifion i ganolfan ddiagnostig yn Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg o fewn saith diwrnod. Mae'r gobaith yw y bydd y cynllun yn cyflymu'r broses ddiagnosis a chynyddu'r nifer o gleifion a dderbyn diagnosis cynnar. Mae cynllun tebyg hefyd yn cael ei sefydlu yn Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot. Os bydd y cynllun peilot yn llwyddiannus, bydd eraill yn y rhanbarth yn ei fabwysiadu.

England achieved a significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning by a large margin with scores of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Captain Alastair Cook also contributed with scores of 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan struggled, with only two players passing 50 runs in the series so far, and their captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment over their performance and shot selection. The series is currently tied, with the next Test scheduled at Edgbaston on August 3.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley as an interim coach and McBryde taking on head coach duties for the third time. McBryde expressed excitement about the opportunity, while the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to appoint assistant coaches for the tour. WRU chief Martyn Phillips mentioned ongoing discussions to finalize the management team. Union chairman Gareth Davies highlighted the potential benefits of Welsh coaches' involvement for the national team and emphasized the developmental opportunities presented by the tour.

In a dramatic match, Hull City came from behind to defeat Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in control, but Hull's fortunes changed in the second half when Robert Snodgrass, returning from injury, scored and assisted Michael Dawson's goal. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas executed a remarkable goalline clearance in the final moments. The win lifted Hull, who remain in the bottom three, while Southampton's manager acknowledged their lack of concentration following a European match.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, around 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist was a local resident, but no further details have been released. The tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses and the B1191 is closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims linked to covert recordings, aiming to "end the agony" before early elections in June. This decision faced condemnation from the opposition and EU officials, with opposition leader Zoran Zaev calling it illegal and urging protests. The crisis began in 2015 with recordings suggesting government officials were involved in vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Zaev has accused the government of extensive corruption and wiretapping, while the government denies these allegations and accuses Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country. EU Commissioner Johannes Hahn stated that Ivanov's actions jeopardize Macedonia's EU membership aspirations.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis emphasizes the importance of avoiding relegation, noting the increased difficulty of bouncing back from the Championship. He reflects on Swansea's successful past since their 2011 Premier League promotion and the impact of management changes since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis believes the current squad can avoid relegation and highlights the significance of the club's history to new players.

Dagenham & Redbridge, who reached League One in 2010, faced relegation after losing to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner for Orient, keeping their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, which first entered the Football League in 2007, now returns to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led them to League One. The team has struggled this season, with the worst goal difference in League Two and a significant drop in goals scored. Following the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan, Leyton Orient's interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the need for professionalism and winning to reach the play-offs. Still acknowledged Dagenham's lack of organization and discipline as key issues this season.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Manager Jürgen Klopp expressed enthusiasm about Gerrard's appointment, noting his desire to become a manager in the future. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and retired after a 19-year career, has won multiple prestigious titles. Although he was linked to the MK Dons managerial position, he felt it was "too soon" for him. He is also pursuing his Uefa A coaching licence, necessary for managing in the Premier League.

McManus scored first for Morton, followed by a deflected strike from Ross Forbes to make it 2-0. Alloa responded with a goal from Kyle McAusland before halftime. However, McManus and Denny Johnstone added two more goals for Morton, securing a comfortable victory.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in poor conditions at three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have since closed. Those operating such schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. An investigation has revealed 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities, raising concerns about potential abuse and radicalization. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, noted that these cases may represent only a small fraction of the issue. While some educational centers operate legally, there are concerns that others exploit home education laws. The government is funding a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the Education Secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases against identified unregistered schools. A consultation on further regulations is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is produced at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh and is part of plans to establish the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes expressed excitement about making the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence." The gin operation is small, fitting into a cowshed, but focuses on local flavors from the Teviot valley. John Henderson from Born in the Borders highlighted the gin distillery's alignment with local sourcing and its connection to the Scottish Borders Brewery. The gin is named after Lilliard, a heroine from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, reflecting the landscape and the strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green, who was over twice the legal driving limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed the profound impact of his death on their family and emphasized the dangers of drunk driving. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in prison for failing to ensure the safety of others, as he was prosecuted under health and safety legislation since the incident occurred on private land. The Health and Safety Executive described the case as extremely tragic and criticized Green's reckless behavior.

Luis Suarez, the 27-year-old Uruguayan striker, is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches with Barcelona after a ruling from the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). While he remains banned from organized matches and must serve the remaining eight games of a nine-match ban for biting an opponent during the 2014 World Cup, he can participate in training and promotional activities. His competitive debut for Barcelona is expected to be on October 26 against Real Madrid. CAS deemed FIFA's total suspension excessive but upheld the majority of the sanctions. Suarez's legal team argued that FIFA's punishment was disproportionate, and the world players' union expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not reduced. Suarez has a history of similar offenses, including previous suspensions for biting and racial abuse.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. Richard noted their preparation involved a week of training on a local athletics track. The race featured a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks and water pistols, and allowed various competitor combinations. Following their victory, Rich and Anna are set to compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond announced that job roles at the DVLA will change with the introduction of an electronic car tax system in October, replacing the paper tax disc. He addressed concerns about potential job losses, assuring that any necessary reductions would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. Mike Hedges, the Swansea East AM, expressed that the minister's response would reassure DVLA employees, despite acknowledging a reduction in job opportunities due to the new direct debit payment system.

Hungary's Foreign Minister, Mr. Szijjarto, stated that the EU should not interfere with Hungary's domestic issues, asserting that Poland would veto any EU attempts to strip Hungary of its voting rights. The EU has raised concerns over Hungary's strict asylum policies, a controversial higher education law potentially threatening the Central European University, and new legislation targeting NGOs. Despite protests from thousands of Hungarians, Szijjarto confirmed Hungary would not retract these laws, emphasizing their national competence. The EU is under pressure to act, with warnings of potential sanctions if no positive changes occur.

The upcoming film features a star playing Mrs. Potts, a role originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Kevin Kline will portray Maurice, Belle's father, while Emma Watson has been cast as Belle. Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will take on the role of Gaston, with Josh Gad as his sidekick LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, the film is set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, with filming starting in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a prominent journalist for the Sunday Times since 1993, was diagnosed with multiple cancers and passed away recently, prompting tributes from colleagues and friends. Known for his sharp wit and fearless writing, Gill described his illness as the "full English" of cancers. His final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, is set to be published in the Sunday Times. Gill faced controversy throughout his career for his provocative comments, including disparaging remarks about various subjects. Despite his struggles with dyslexia, he built a successful writing career, starting in the 1980s. He was married twice and had four children. His death has left a profound impact on the journalism community, with many expressing their admiration for his talent and character.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a rapper performing in Ulan Bator, was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomat, suffering severe injuries that left him in a coma for about 10 days. Reports indicate he was struck with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, claiming local media reports are distorted. Sukhbaatar wore a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol, which has been misinterpreted as a hate symbol. His family and lawyer denied claims that he made Nazi references during the performance. The case is under investigation, with authorities stating that the suspect's diplomatic status did not prevent his arrest.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion plans on Monday, resulting in charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, prompting the Metropolitan Police to review airport security.

Nick Selman scored a mature 101 runs for Glamorgan, marking his second first-class century, despite being dropped early in his innings. His performance was crucial as wickets fell regularly due to Gloucestershire's seamers, Matt Taylor and Craig Miles, who maintained pressure throughout the day. Aneurin Donald contributed 36 runs, while Glamorgan managed to secure a bonus point. Gloucestershire's batting struggled in challenging conditions, ending the day with the match evenly poised. Glamorgan's captain, Michael Hogan, led the team in the absence of Jacques Rudolph. Selman expressed relief at returning to form after a series of low scores, while Taylor noted the challenges ahead for Gloucestershire's batsmen against a strong bowling attack.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after making online threats to ambush police officers following a false report of a crime. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes, who was intoxicated during the incidents, planned to shoot officers responding to the false report on the Dee Estuary. He has a prior conviction for firearm possession in 2009. Despite his legal team's claims that he did not intend to harm himself or police, the court was concerned due to his bail status for previous firearms offences. The Hope Line Crisis Centre, where he communicated, provides support for individuals in distress.

In a recent match, after being reduced to 8-2, a team scored 255-7, with Davies and Foakes contributing significantly with a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire's chase faltered due to Stuart Meaker's three-wicket haul, which included key players Bairstow and Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire was all out for 236. They aimed to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 but faced setbacks, including dropped catches. Surrey's captain praised the team's performance, while Yorkshire's captain expressed disappointment over their inability to capitalize on good white-ball cricket this season.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST due to a malfunctioning pump that couldn't handle incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the boat and towing it to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, announced that she will not participate in the Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine studies, with exams scheduled for May. She recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships and expressed disappointment about missing the Commonwealths but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. Muir is considering competing in the World Indoor Championships in March and feels she is in good shape. She achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14:52.07 and is optimistic about her future in athletics, believing she has several more Olympic opportunities ahead.

In his BBC Sport column, Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's struggles to replicate last season's title challenge, highlighting their current distance from competing for the title and the challenges faced by manager Brendan Rodgers. He notes that Liverpool's overachievement last season has led to unrealistic expectations among fans. Key issues include the loss of goals following Luis Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injuries, as well as inadequate replacements in the forward line. Savage emphasizes the team's lack of intensity and effectiveness in both attack and defense, particularly in set-pieces. He also reflects on Steven Gerrard's ongoing battle to secure his future with the club, acknowledging his importance despite concerns about his age and performance. Savage predicts a tough match against Chelsea, who he believes are currently superior to Liverpool. Overall, he sees Gerrard as a vital player for Liverpool's future, despite the mental and physical challenges he faces.

A £45 million facility will be constructed at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, featuring primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, who became an English teacher before writing full-time, is known for his first novel, Remedy Is None, and the Laidlaw trilogy, earning the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster, contributing to Scotland's political and sporting life. He passed away on December 5 at his Glasgow home.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated due to a sea mine, believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s, spotted on Monday. Residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors, and an exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea. Ferry services faced disruptions, but local authorities emphasized that the evacuation was precautionary and there was no immediate danger. The mine's condition made it necessary to move it to a safer location for further handling. Inverclyde Council thanked residents for their cooperation during the evacuation.

The passage discusses funding changes for various sports in the lead-up to the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, which is £2m less than the funding for the Rio Games. Notably, badminton has had its funding completely cut, despite achieving a bronze medal in Rio, leading to strong criticism from Badminton England's chief executive. Other sports like cycling have also seen significant funding reductions. UK Sport aims to set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. The funding decisions are based on prioritizing medal potential, with some sports, including baseball and karate, being added to the program. UK Sport emphasizes the need for strategic investment to maintain the success seen in previous Olympics.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks will be built at East Cliff in Bournemouth, leading to the demolition of three Victorian hotels. Despite strong objections from English Heritage regarding the impact on the conservation area, councillors approved the project, citing benefits for tourism and improved living conditions for older residents. The development will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. While the council received 246 supportive letters, 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society opposed the demolition, emphasizing the historical significance of the existing buildings.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely, 24, while off-duty in Brecon. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8 after being found guilty of the attack, which occurred outside a bar called The Cellar on May 8. CCTV footage showed Boyd being punched and beaten until he was unconscious. Vallely had been drinking heavily prior to the incident and bragged about being the "hardest man in Brecon." His friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The community was shocked by the violence, and Boyd's family described him as a loving and caring individual with a promising future. They expressed their grief over the loss and highlighted the support they received from the community.

Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by mutual agreement following an error that led to voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been initiated, and Mr. Travers expressed his enjoyment of his time at Barnet and confidence in the borough's future. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve temporarily in his place. On election day, many voters were not on the register, raising concerns about the fairness of the election results. Barnet Council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. The investigation will conclude by the end of May, focusing on the electoral arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum.

In a match where Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1, Josh Gillies opened the scoring for Gateshead with a free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before halftime through Sean Newton's set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header from a cross. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, acknowledged Wrexham's strong first-half performance but praised his team's improved play in the second half. Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment in his team's second-half performance, noting missed chances despite having opportunities.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, with Mozambique following closely.

The OneWeb project aims to create a network of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband access, particularly for schools. Airbus is adapting its manufacturing processes to produce these satellites at a lower cost and higher volume, using assembly line methods similar to those in automotive and aerospace industries. The first assembly line has been established in Toulouse, France, with plans for additional lines in Florida. The launch of the satellites will require a significant rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles booked for deployment. OneWeb has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is working on securing loans for the project. The UK Space Agency is involved in regulatory oversight, particularly concerning space debris mitigation, as the project aims to de-orbit redundant satellites within two years to minimize collision risks. The initiative is seen as a potential model for future satellite manufacturing, although bespoke satellite designs will still be necessary for certain missions.

Mr. Swinney criticized the UK government's recent spending review for placing "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's public expenditure, stating that the Scottish government's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He highlighted that real terms cuts imposed by the chancellor will continue until 2020, with over £1 billion in cuts still to come. Despite these challenges, Swinney emphasized the Scottish government's commitment to protect key services like schools, hospitals, and police. In response, a UK government spokesman noted that the Scottish government would have £390 million more to spend next year, and criticized it for focusing on grievances rather than utilizing its new powers effectively. Labour's Jackie Baillie called for a long-term budget and criticized the Scottish government for its approach to austerity.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities and their families regarding the lack of accessible toilet facilities, particularly Changing Places toilets, which are designed to accommodate those who require additional support. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners are advocating for these to be made compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers and sports venues. Lorna Fillingham, a mother of a disabled child, highlights the stress of inadequate facilities, while others share similar sentiments about the psychological impact of not having appropriate changing spaces. Although Changing Places specifications have been recommended since 2009, they are not mandatory, leading to inconsistencies in accessibility. Campaigners are pushing for changes in building regulations to ensure these facilities are included in new constructions, as seen in positive examples like Arsenal Football Club's installation of a Changing Places toilet.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's defends its practices, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees and supports their operations. The complaint is backed by the Service Employees International Union and other European unions, which argue that McDonald's dominant market position negatively impacts franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will review the complaint and may investigate if the allegations are substantiated. The consumer organisations claim that franchisees are locked into long contracts and pay above-market lease rates, resulting in reduced consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, contributing to significant revenues for the company.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, has gained significant traction after he was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. Initially intended as a way for his family to seek support and prayers, the hashtag #prayforjosh went viral, starting from posts by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is a pastor. The campaign has reached over 79,000 people and led to a billboard being erected in Holywood by an anonymous donor. The community, including Josh's classmates, has shown overwhelming support, demonstrating a global response to his situation.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in the UK as part of a military reorganization. Conservative MP Chris Davies criticized the decision, highlighting the barracks' long history since 1805 and its significance in military conflicts. He plans to launch a petition against the closure, expressing concerns about local unemployment and the potential impact on military tourism. Although the barracks employs around 175 staff, job losses are not anticipated. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced the establishment of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and noted other closures, including Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and a Sennybridge depot in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of the negative effects on local livelihoods.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting concerns that EU-registered boats may be allowed to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal. While fishing communities largely supported leaving the EU, the House of Lords report warns they risk being marginalized in negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized by the industry, which sees Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters. However, the report emphasizes the need for continued market access to the EU, which may require trade-offs, including potential EU access to UK waters. The report also suggests retaining certain CFP elements and warns of the complications of managing fisheries across different UK regions post-Brexit. Despite these challenges, some in the industry remain optimistic about future opportunities, citing recent increases in allowable catches. The government aims to ensure fair access to quotas and sustainable fisheries management as negotiations proceed.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of significant leaks regarding US surveillance practices, which he found "horrifying." The leaks indicated that the NSA has extensive access to personal data, including chat logs, voice traffic, and social media information, facilitated by a program called Prism that allegedly allows "backdoor" access to major tech companies' servers. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records, raising concerns about privacy and data protection laws. Officials argue that national security needs outweigh privacy concerns, with President Obama stating that complete security and privacy cannot coexist. The implications of these surveillance practices extend internationally, as US laws like the Patriot Act affect data stored abroad. Privacy advocates express alarm over the potential for widespread data access by the US government, with Snowden emphasizing his opposition to living in a society that records every action and conversation.

The passage discusses the backing of OpenAI by notable figures and companies, including Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, and highlights its focus on research aimed at benefiting humanity without financial constraints. It mentions concerns from scientists about AI potentially threatening humanity, with Musk labeling it as a significant existential threat. Conversely, some experts believe the risks are minimal. OpenAI emphasizes the importance of developing AI that enhances human capabilities and is distributed safely. The venture plans to spend only a small portion of the pledged $1 billion in the coming years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June and has since received over 5,000 friend requests on Facebook, which he cannot accept due to the platform's limit. Despite his brain injury affecting his speech, he has maintained his personality and humor, now speaking unaided. He dedicates 12 hours daily to gym and rehabilitation, and actively raises money for military charities. His mother noted the overwhelming support he has received, with significant online engagement and requests for appearances with the torch. Facebook suggested he consider creating a public page due to his public figure status. The Olympic torch relay will involve 8,000 people over 70 days, culminating in the opening ceremony in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the U.S. was 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, remaining stable after three years of increases. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, while the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%. The poverty rate had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new deal lasting until 2019. He is known for being a short-format specialist and holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and impact on the team's success in the T20 Blast final. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League, is set to return to Lancashire for an upcoming T20 Blast match against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bids for their sale due by 23 January. No preservation proposals have been submitted, and viewings for interested bidders are scheduled for late February and March, with a final decision expected in spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt emphasizes the importance of giving the ships a "noble second life," preferably as a reef and diving attraction for tourism. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options for the frigates to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed for anti-submarine warfare but evolved into versatile surface combatants.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced ongoing racial and political tensions, beginning with a coup by indigenous Fijians that overthrew an Indian-dominated government. This led to a series of events, including a constitution favoring indigenous Fijian supremacy and a 2000 coup where the first ethnic Indian prime minister was held hostage. These upheavals harmed Fiji's economy, particularly tourism, and damaged its international standing, culminating in a military takeover in 2006. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to a lack of democratic progress but agreed to hold elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of diplomatic ties and Commonwealth membership. The population is primarily divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep-seated segregation. Fiji's economy, reliant on sugar and tourism, is diverse but struggles with trade and budget deficits, making it a significant recipient of foreign aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is striving to meet the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline. He reported that shipments of chemical weapons were attacked en route to the port of Latakia. Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where recent attacks have resulted in numerous civilian casualties. He accused the US of supporting terrorist groups in Syria and denied reports of rebels seizing control of Aleppo's central prison. The US has expressed concern over the slow progress of chemical weapons removal, with only 4% of Syria's declared stockpile having been shipped out. Russia has urged Syria to complete the transfer by March, while the OPCW acknowledged that security issues have hindered the destruction process. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

Mukherjee's novel The Lives Of Others, set in 1960s Calcutta, is the favorite to win the Booker Prize, which is now open to all English-language authors. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall. The shortlist includes British authors Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, and others, as well as American writers Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler, and Australian Richard Flanagan. Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is the best-selling book on the list. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling, and the ceremony will be covered by BBC News. This year marks the 46th Booker Prize, with each shortlisted author receiving £2,500.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing a court ruling that lifted a media ban on revealing his identity in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments regarding this appeal, with an interim injunction remaining in place until the hearing concludes. PJS, who has young children and a public spouse, argues for his right to privacy against allegations of extra-marital activities, which he claims began in 2009. The Court of Appeal previously ruled in his favor, preventing his identification, but the publishers of the Sun On Sunday challenged this, citing widespread publication of the story elsewhere. The judges noted that confidentiality had likely been lost due to the extensive dissemination of details online, making it difficult to maintain the injunction.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was purchased for £345.5 million in August. Plans are underway to enhance parking, alleviate traffic congestion, and improve the appearance of the units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White noted that the new owners are collaborating with the council to address planning concerns, viewing Fosse Park as a key investment to enhance the gateway into the city. Paul Clarke from Crown Estates emphasized the need to improve the quality of common areas and facilities, as the park has become outdated in recent years.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" and was held for content review before its scheduled release. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit regarding this moment, despite homosexuality being illegal in the country. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification," but a new release date is pending. Local cinemas are offering refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The film's director, Bill Condon, described the moment involving the character LeFou's feelings for Gaston. The review decision sparked criticism online, with many users expressing discontent over the censorship.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated individuals must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost around £1,000, despite potential fines of up to £20,000 for non-compliance. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants often express concerns about eviction and poor living conditions due to a lack of affordable housing. Nationally, HMO licensing applies to properties with three or more storeys occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, specific areas have been designated for licensing since 2013 and 2015. While most landlords comply, some resist, leading to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are working to avoid a second election, with Fianna Fáil willing to support a minority government but not a government program. Water charges are a key issue, with Fianna Fáil advocating for their removal while Fine Gael supports their continuation. Following the recent election, Fine Gael holds 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party has achieved a majority government, and TDs have not yet elected a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on one of its car decks while approximately 27km from Mallorca. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship, with at least three individuals injured, one seriously. The cause of the fire remains unknown. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue, and the passengers were taken back to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists were arranged to provide counselling at the port. The Balearic Islands port authority indicated that the Sorrento might sink due to the fire. Distress signals were sent out at 13:50 local time, and a full evacuation was eventually ordered as the fire intensified.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about individuals, including students, allegedly voting twice, which is illegal. It suggested improving the integration of individual electoral registers to identify duplicate entries. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June election, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registration applications following the announcement of a snap election, but concerns about duplicate applications persist, with estimates suggesting 30% to 70% may be duplicates. The lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service complicates verification. The Commission emphasized the need for clearer registration information and a verification function. While some individuals may legally register in multiple constituencies, voting twice in a general election is a serious offense. Labour's Cat Smith cautioned against making registration harder for young people and students while acknowledging the seriousness of double voting.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star player at the University of Nebraska and NFL rookie, reportedly took his own life at the age of 40. His NFL career included stints with the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, but he faced numerous legal troubles, including convictions for assault. He was serving a prison sentence of over 30 years and had been placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his former cellmate. A judge recently found sufficient evidence to try him for the death of Damion Soward. Despite his intelligence and positive qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and personal demons, according to his former coach, Tom Osborne.

Private Derby XXX was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester celebrating eight years of the Mercian Regiment, receiving his honour from Brigadier Andrew Williams. The Swaledale ram, recognized as a soldier, was promoted for "good behaviour" and is the 30th mascot ram since the mid-19th Century. He joined the regiment in February 2014, has an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season. Throughout his career, he has participated in events like switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

The passage describes a thrilling football match where Liverpool, under manager Jurgen Klopp, achieved a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund, showcasing emotion, excitement, and a remarkable comeback. Initially trailing 2-0, Liverpool rallied to score four goals, inspired by Klopp's motivational leadership and the passionate support of their fans. The match was marked by a vibrant atmosphere at Anfield, commemorating the Hillsborough disaster, and highlighted the transition from doubt to belief among players and supporters. Klopp emphasized the importance of winning before touching the "This Is Anfield" sign, reflecting his desire to instill respect and ambition in the team. The victory not only brought Liverpool closer to the Champions League but also reinforced Klopp's identity and influence on the club.

The passage discusses a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, where UK government officials, including Mr. Davis, emphasized the importance of keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations. Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings to facilitate a two-way information flow and allow devolved administrations to express their views. While he described the meeting as constructive, Mr. Russell highlighted the need for greater transparency regarding the UK government's strategic intentions, particularly concerning EU market access and membership in the single market, which he deemed essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. Additionally, the UK government is awaiting a Supreme Court appeal regarding the triggering of Article 50, with the Scottish government planning to oppose the UK government's position in court.

Dr. Sandra Corr examines Daisy, a cloned sheep, as part of a study on the health and aging of cloned animals, particularly in relation to the original cloned sheep, Dolly. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, including four clones of Dolly, who was the first cloned mammal. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and to assess their health, focusing on conditions like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Concerns exist that cloning may transfer "age-memory," potentially leading to premature aging. The results of the study, which involve extensive health assessments, will be published soon, but the cloned sheep currently appear healthy as they approach their ninth and tenth birthdays.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten horse won a race, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters, and will compete in the Oaks in Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Shutter Speed, who previously beat Enable, secured a fifth Musidora win for Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori, who noted the horse's potential on better ground. Gosden is cautious about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes, which may affect his participation in the Derby.

The passage discusses the fluctuating value of the pound against the dollar and euro, which initially fell but began to recover before declining again. The volatility index has reached levels reminiscent of the 2008 financial crisis, driven by uncertainty over the upcoming referendum on EU membership. Polls indicate a tightening race between the Leave and Remain campaigns, causing increased market volatility. Hedge funds are betting on a further decline in sterling, reflecting concerns about the economic impact of a potential Brexit. Asian stock markets also fell significantly, while the FTSE 100 experienced a modest decline. Despite these concerns, some Leave campaigners argue that the pound has strengthened since March, benefiting UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. Despite a recent loss to Barrow, who are on a nine-game unbeaten streak, manager Cowley expressed optimism about the team's performance and acknowledged the challenges of being a part-time team. He emphasized the remarkable progress made so far and the importance of embracing the current challenges.

The passage discusses a significant change in Northern Ireland's planning system, set to take effect in April 2015, where local councils will take over planning decisions from the Planning Service, allowing elected politicians to accept or reject developments. Michael Corr views this as a positive opportunity for local councils to shape their communities, but concerns arise regarding politicians' skills in urban planning and the potential for discrimination reminiscent of past issues in the 1960s. Environmental group Friends of the Earth warns of the need for strict conduct codes to ensure fairness and transparency, citing risks of favoritism and close ties between developers and political parties. There are also debates about the implications of political donations and the need for transparency in this new system.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot multiple times, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. Found by her owner, Sarah Nisbett, in Winchburgh, Teenie is now learning to walk again. The incident has raised concerns about air weapon licensing in Scotland, as a consultation last year showed 87% of respondents opposed stricter regulations. Scottish SPCA officials are urging anyone with information about the shooting to come forward, emphasizing the need for a licensing regime to prevent such incidents and ensure responsible ownership of air guns.

Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool on a long-term contract, becoming the club's second most expensive signing after they triggered a release clause in his contract. The 24-year-old Belgian international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa and aims to help Liverpool win trophies. The club struggled with scoring last season, finishing sixth in the Premier League, prompting manager Brendan Rodgers to strengthen the attack with Benteke and other signings like Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge expressed confidence in Benteke's ability to succeed at Liverpool, highlighting his strong presence and goal-scoring potential.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement linked to tablet use in schools, despite their increasing prevalence, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them. Researchers noted that while tablets are common, they cannot definitively connect their use to improved student outcomes. However, head teachers reported positive impacts, particularly in motivating disengaged students and involving families when tablets are taken home. The number of tablets in schools is expected to rise significantly, and technology's role in education is anticipated to grow. A separate study indicated that touch-screen computers may help boys and disadvantaged pupils learn to read. Overall, the integration of technology in schools reflects students' everyday lives and prepares them for future work environments.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs showcasing children's lives in Liverpool over more than 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition highlights both joyful moments and the harsh realities of childhood, including images of children at play and those who had to work. The oldest photograph dates back to 1887, depicting the Rollo siblings at a fancy dress ball. The exhibition aims to provide a thought-provoking social history of childhood experiences in the city and is open until September 25.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join a National League rival, potentially facing his former team on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, has a history with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership qualities and noted Keating's eagerness to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six matches.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization and imposes stricter penalties for child violence, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera stated that the legislation addresses Bolivia's needs as a poor country and aims to balance rights with reality. Over 500,000 children currently work in various sectors, often under harsh conditions. The law, signed in the absence of President Evo Morales, seeks to combat extreme poverty, despite the International Labour Organisation's stance against child labor under 15.
